clean_content:
Definition / general

* Malignant tumor that consists of both squamous cell carcinoma and ductal adenocarcinoma components ([Digestion 2005;72:104](16172546), [Cancer 2003;99:372](14681946), [Int J Pancreatol 1999;26:85](10597404), [Arch Surg 1999;134:599](10367867))

Essential features

* Malignant tumor consisting of both squamous cell carcinoma and ductal adenocarcinoma components ([Digestion 2005;72:104](16172546), [Cancer 2003;99:372](14681946), [Int J Pancreatol 1999;26:85](10597404), [Arch Surg 1999;134:599](10367867))* Closely related to and admixed with [pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma (PDAC)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html); some require 30% squamous differentiation for the diagnosis of adenosquamous carcinoma* Cases with < 30% of squamous component also behave like adenosquamous carcinoma and can be acknowledged as PDAC with focal (< 30%) squamous differentiation* Metastatic tumor can be solely composed of the glandular component ([Mod Pathol 2001;14:443](11353055))* Often has necrotic and cystic components ([Arch Surg 1999;134:599](10367867))* Behaves even worse than ordinary PDAC

ICD coding

* ICD-O: [8560/3](https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/96612/9789241548496_eng.pdf#page=76) - adenosquamous carcinoma

Epidemiology

* Accounts for about ~2% of exocrine pancreatic malignancies* M:F = 2:1* Mean age of 65 years ([Arch Surg 1999;134:599](10367867))

Sites

* Body and tail of the pancreas is more often affected than the head ([J Surg Res 2012;174:12](21816433))

Etiology

* Ionizing radiation of the pancreas may predispose to the occurrence of adenosquamous carcinoma ([Mod Pathol 2001;14:443](11353055))

Diagnosis

* Generally discovered with radiology and confirmed on fine needle aspiration biopsy (FNAB) or resection

Radiology description

* Similar to [pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html) but many cases present with more round, lobulated lesion with extensive central necrosis* Portal venous system may contain tumor thrombus ([Abdom Radiol (NY) 2016;41:508](27039322))

Radiology images

Contributed by Orhun Çığ Taşkın, M.D.  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin03new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin03new.jpg)

Cystic and necrotic changes

Prognostic factors

* Similar to PDAC, stage is the most important prognostic factor

Case reports

* 63 year old man and 69 year old woman with adenosquamous carcinoma of the pancreas ([Annu Rev Pathol 2020;15:97](36309754))* 66 year old woman with adenosquamous carcinoma of the pancreas ([Clin Case Rep 2022;10:e6181](35937009))* 80 year old Japanese woman with adenosquamous carcinoma coexisting with intraductal papillary mucinous neoplasm of the pancreas ([J Med Case Rep 2023;17:72](36859393))

Treatment

* Similar to [pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html)* If the tumor is operable, complete surgical resection, followed by adjuvant chemotherapy; increasingly neoadjuvant therapy is utilized just as in PDAC ([Hum Pathol 2010;41:113](19801164),
    [J Gastrointest Oncol 2015;6:115](25830031))* Even more aggressive than ordinary PDAC with a median survival of < 1 year ([Gastrointest Cancer Res 2013;6:75](23936547))* Based on the immunohistochemical results, 11% of patients are assumed to be potential candidates for therapy with antibodies against PD-1 / PDL1 ([Pancreatology 2021;21:920](33773917))

Gross description

* Large, firm mass of the pancreas, with ill defined borders, often with necrotic component, with or without cystic areas* Some cases are more demarcated* Reference: [World J Gastrointest Oncol 2015;7:132](26380056)

Microscopic (histologic) description

* Adenocarcinoma component can bare all the characteristics of classic [pancreatic ductal adenocarcinoma](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/pancreasductal.html)* Squamous component can show keratinization with intercellular bridges or sheets of squamous cells with keratohyaline granules or pearls
    + Some are adenoacanthoma-like, with bland mature squamous elements, whereas others are more basal-like (with high N:C ratio and basophilic appearance)* Adenocarcinoma and squamous components can vary greatly in the amount and distribution* Sarcomatous component can also be encountered ([Anticancer Res 2019;39:4575](31366562))

Microscopic (histologic) images

Contributed by Orhun Çığ Taşkın, M.D., Raul S. Gonzalez, M.D. and AFIP  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin08anew.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin08anew.jpg)
 
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin07new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin07new.jpg)
 
[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousgonzalez01new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousgonzalez01new.jpg)

Glandular and squamous components

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin08bnew.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin08bnew.jpg)

p63

  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP1new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP1new.jpg)

Adenocarcinoma and squamous carcinoma

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP2new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP2new.jpg)

Squamous components

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP3new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP3new.jpg)

Mucoepidermoid pattern

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP4anew.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP4anew.jpg)

CAM5.2

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP4bnew.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamousAFIP4bnew.jpg)

CK13

Cytology description

* Squamous component may be undersampled but malignant squamous cells are highly significant for the diagnosis ([Acta Cytol 2013;57:139](23406837))* Glandular and squamous components can both be distinguished* Dense globules, silhouettes of squamous cells, anucleate squames, atypical cytoplasm and enlarged pyknotic nuclei are present in the prominent necrotic background* Sheets and clusters of atypical cells with nuclei of variable sizes and shapes ([Cancer 2003;99:372](14681946))

Cytology images

Contributed by Orhun Çığ Taşkın, M.D.  

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin04new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin04new.jpg)

Pap stain

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin05new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin05new.jpg)

Cell block

[![](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin06new.jpg)](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/imgau/pancreasadenosquamoustaskin06new.jpg)

Cell block, p40

Positive stains

* Immunoreactivity for [AE1 / AE3](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsae1ae3.html) is identified* [p63](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsp63.html),
    [p40](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsdeltaNp63.html),
    [high molecular weight cytokeratin](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsck34be12.html) specifically highlights the squamous component ([Mod Pathol 2005;18:1193](15976814), [Mod Pathol 2009;22:651](19270646))

Negative stains

* Loss of [SMAD4 / DPC4](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/stainsdpc4.html) protein expression

Molecular / cytogenetics description

* [*KRAS*](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/molecularKRAS.html) mutations occur in almost all cases ([Mod Pathol 2001;14:443](11353055), [Mod Pathol 2009;22:651](19270646))* *TP53* mutations and 3p loss are commonly encountered* Recently discovered basal-like molecular subtype of PDAC is believed to also represent adenosquamous carcinoma ([Nature 2016;531:47](26909576))* Both components are believed to originate from the same progenitor cell ([J Pathol 2017;243:155](28722109))* Susceptibility genes including *MAP3K1, PDE4DIP* and *BCR* are frequently mutated in the germlines of patients ([Cancer Biomark 2020;27:389](31958074))

Sample pathology report

* Pancreas, resection:
  + Adenosquamous carcinoma (see synoptic report)

Differential diagnosis

* **Pure squamous cell carcinoma**:
  + Extremely rare; most cases contain a small amount of glandular component, which is enough to call the tumor adenosquamous carcinoma* [Metastasis of adenosquamous carcinoma of the lung](https://www.pathologyoutlines.com/topic/lungtumoradenosquamous.html):
    + Needs to be carefully excluded ([Virchows Arch 2004;444:527](15057558))
